Authors: Henrik Enghoff, Gitte Petersen, Ole Seberg
Title:
The aberrant millipede genus Pteridoiulus and its position in
a revised molecular phylogeny of the family Julidae (Diplopoda,
Julida).
Abstract:
A phylogenetic analysis of 62 species of the Palaearctic
millipede family Julidae, including the aberrant genus Pteridoiulus, was
made based on partial sequences of the mitochondrial 16S rRNA and the
nuclear 28S rRNA genes. Data sets were analysed individually and
combined using direct optimization in POY. 16S rDNA and 28S rDNA
sequences vary from 410 -449 bp and from 467-525 bp, respectively.
Searches were performed under six different gap opening costs, extension
gap cost = 1, substitution cost = 2. The optimal gap opening cost was
set to 4, and the effect of gap opening costs from 1-6 investigated.
Incongruence length difference values were used to select the preferred
tree. Data partitions were aligned individually using MAFTT and run in
TNT with gaps treated as a fifth state, and as missing, and the
alignments were input in a maximum likelihood analysis. The order Julida
and the Julidae were monophyletic under all POY settings, and in TNT and
ML analyses. Pteridoiulus was always found to be sister to another
monotypic genus, Heteroiulus. The Pteridoiulus+Heteroiulus clade lacks
morphological support. The distribution pattern, Pteridoiulus in the
eastern Alps, Heteroiulus in the southern Alps seems unique: similar
patterns involve pairs of very similar species.
